In the seventeenth century, “consciousness” began to take
on a uniquely modern sense. This transition was sparked by new
theories of mind and ideas, and it connected with other important
issues of debate during the seventeenth century, including debates
over the transparency of the mental, animal consciousness, and innate
ideas. Additionally, consciousness was tied closely to moral identity,
with both French and Latin lacking even a linguistic distinction
between consciousness and conscience (i.e., a moral sensibility). This
semantic shift marked a philosophical division between the
psychological or phenomenal aspects of thought and a moral sensibility
as well. The discussions on all of these topics were rich and varied
in the seventeenth century—the article below provides a view
from forty thousand feet.
